title: Josphat Kinyumu
text: Josphat Kinyumu is a skilled professional with many years of experience in technology risk and IT audits. He has worked with well-known companies in the UK and East Africa, helping businesses in industries like banking, energy, insurance, manufacturing, and telecom stay secure and meet regulations.

title: Josphat Kinyumu
text:
üíº Professional Journey
Josphat currently works at Aberdeen as an IT Internal Audit Manager, where he looks after technology risks, IT controls, and how well systems are managed within one of the UK‚Äôs top financial firms.
His career started at PwC East Africa, where he joined as a graduate trainee and later led tech audits for some of Kenya‚Äôs biggest banks and insurance firms helping them meet regulatory standards.
He later moved to the UK to work at KPMG, spending several years as a Manager in External Audit, leading IT audit work for major clients. After that, he joined Forvis Mazars, where he headed a team of IT audit specialists focused on banking clients.

title: Josphat Kinyumu
text:
üåç Thought Leadership & Contributions
Across roles, Josphat has been a trusted voice on aligning IT systems with financial reporting and compliance objectives. He has contributed to tech-enabled audit transformation, supported diversity initiatives, and mentored emerging professionals with a focus on clarity, growth, and inclusiveness. His interest in bridging technology and governance continues to fuel meaningful dialogue and collaborative learning, especially within multicultural and cross-functional teams.

title: Josphat Kinyumu
text:
üéì Education & Qualifications
Josphat‚Äôs education gives him a strong mix of tech know-how and business understanding:

Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA)

Certified Public Accountant (CPA)

BSc in Computer Science, First Class Honours, University of Nairobi

title: Josphat Kinyumu
text:
üí¨ In His Words

‚ÄúAudit isn‚Äôt just about spotting problems. It‚Äôs about building trust, improving systems, and helping others feel confident. I love learning, and every project gives me a chance to help connect technology with smart decision-making.‚Äù

title: Josphat Kinyumu
text:
üåê Connect with Josphat

LinkedIn: Josphat Kyalo Kinyumu

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
On 14 January 2024, the Kenyan Community in Scotland hosted a memorable Networking Mixer at The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon in Edinburgh. The afternoon was filled with energy, laughter, and meaningful conversations, bringing together a vibrant group of Kenyan professionals and friends.
A huge thank you to everyone who made time to attend. It was heartwarming to see so many familiar faces and meet new members of our growing community. The positive atmosphere reflected the strength and unity of Kenyans living in Scotland.

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
On 14 January 2024, the Kenyan Community in Scotland hosted a memorable Networking Mixer at The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon in Edinburgh. The afternoon was filled with energy, laughter, and meaningful conversations, bringing together a vibrant group of Kenyan professionals and friends.
A huge thank you to everyone who made time to attend. It was heartwarming to see so many familiar faces and meet new members of our growing community. The positive atmosphere reflected the strength and unity of Kenyans living in Scotland.

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
Event Highlights

Lively Networking Sessions: Attendees engaged in dynamic discussions, exchanging ideas, career experiences, and professional insights across diverse industries including healthcare, IT, education, business, and the arts.
Sharing Life in Edinburgh: Many shared personal journeys about settling and thriving in Edinburgh, offering invaluable advice to newcomers.
Strengthening Community Bonds: Friendships were rekindled and new relationships were formed, reinforcing the importance of staying connected and supporting each other.
Youth and Family Engagement: It was also wonderful to see younger members of the community present, adding to the joyful and inclusive spirit of the day.

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
A Special Thanks
Our heartfelt appreciation goes to our venue, The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon, for providing a welcoming, comfortable, and relaxed environment. The excellent service and cozy setting contributed immensely to the success of the event.

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
Reflections and Next Steps
This mixer was more than just an event; it was a reminder of the strength that lies in community. It highlighted our shared experiences, our aspirations, and the endless possibilities that collaboration brings.
We are excited about the future and are already planning more events to continue building a strong, supportive, and thriving Kenyan community network in Scotland.
Stay tuned for announcements on upcoming workshops, social events, and mentorship programs. Together, we are building a brighter future!

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text: On Saturday, 21st June 2025, members and friends of the Kenyan Community in Scotland came together for a stunning summer hike in the Glenshee region, conquering two magnificent Munros: Glas Tulaichean (1,051‚ÄØm / 3,448‚ÄØft) and C√†rn an R√¨gh (1,029‚ÄØm / 3,376‚ÄØft).

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üåÑ The Day Unfolded
We departed Edinburgh at 6:00 AM, having assembled at Usher Hall with excitement and anticipation. After arriving around 8:00 AM at the Dalmunzie Hotel near Spittal of Glenshee, we began our 19 km circular hike under gradually clearing skies. The trail offered a mixture of gentle climbs and steeper sections through glens and ridges, revealing breathtaking Highland vistas.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üì∏ Journey Highlights

From Dalmunzie Hotel to Glas Tulaichean Summit

The journey begins at Dalmunzie: packs on, boots laced, spirits high.

Open terrain and distant peaks set the tone for the first Munro.

Final push to Glas Tulaichean with encouragement at every step.



Glas Tulaichean Summit Moments

A moment of triumph at 1,051 metres: smiles and cheers all around.

Resting at the top with Highland views all around.



Trek to C√†rn an R√¨gh

Descending Glas Tulaichean before the next climb begins.

The trail to C√†rn an R√¨gh opens wide as the next summit comes into view.



C√†rn an R√¨gh Summit Celebration

Second Munro conquered: a well-earned sense of achievement.



Journey Back to Dalmunzie Hotel

A red tent dots the shore of Loch nan Eun: a quiet reminder of solitude amidst vast Highland beauty.

Feet tired but hearts full, we descended together through gentle paths and forested edges.
 With Dalmunzie in sight, conversations turned to food, photos, and future hikes.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üí¨ Reflections
For many participants, this was their first Munro experience, and what a perfect introduction it was. From shared snacks and supportive steps to scenic breaks and collective encouragement, the hike embodied resilience, joy, and community.
This adventure reminded us of what lies at the heart of our community: togetherness, wellness, and exploration.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üôå Thank You
A huge thanks to everyone who made this event successful, from organising transport and guiding the route to bringing contagious enthusiasm. You made it memorable!

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üì¨ Stay Involved
Don‚Äôt miss future adventures!
üëâ Join our mailing list or sign up to volunteer

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text: Healthcare in Scotland is free at the point of use through the NHS (National Health Service) - as long as you‚Äôve paid the Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS) as part of your visa application. This guide helps you navigate NHS Scotland services, register with a doctor, and know what to do in case of emergencies.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text: Healthcare in Scotland is free at the point of use through the NHS (National Health Service) - as long as you‚Äôve paid the Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS) as part of your visa application. This guide helps you navigate NHS Scotland services, register with a doctor, and know what to do in case of emergencies.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üß≠ 1. NHS Scotland Basics

NHS Scotland provides healthcare to all residents, including international newcomers who have paid the IHS.
You don‚Äôt pay for hospital care or GP visits.
You may pay a small charge for prescriptions or dental treatment.
Services are based on clinical need ‚Äî not your immigration status, as long as you‚Äôre eligible.

üîó Learn about NHS Scotland üîó Explore NHS services and support

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
ü©∫ 2. Registering with a GP
A General Practitioner (GP) is your first contact for non-emergency medical issues.

üìå Steps to register:

Find a GP practice near your home
üîó Find a GP practice
Call or visit the practice to request registration
Complete a registration form (can be done online or in person)
Provide ID (e.g.¬†passport, BRP) and proof of address (e.g.¬†tenancy agreement)

Once registered, you can: - Book GP appointments
- Get referrals to specialists
- Request repeat prescriptions
- Access mental health support
üìå Tip: Register early ‚Äî don‚Äôt wait until you‚Äôre unwell.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üöë 3. Emergencies & Urgent Care

üÜò Life-threatening emergency?
Dial 999 for an ambulance, fire, or police.


üò∑ Not an emergency, but need urgent advice?
Dial 111 to speak to NHS 24, available 24/7.
Other urgent services: - Minor injuries units (for cuts, sprains, burns)
- Walk-in centres (in some cities)
- Out-of-hours GP services

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üíä 4. Medicines & Prescriptions

Prescriptions are free in Scotland.
Your GP will give you a prescription, which you take to a pharmacy (‚Äúchemist‚Äù).
Most large supermarkets (e.g.¬†Tesco, Asda) and high street chains (e.g.¬†Boots) have pharmacies.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üò¨ 5. Dental & Eye Care

Dental care is not always free ‚Äî but it‚Äôs partially covered by the NHS.
You must register with an NHS dentist (some waiting lists may apply).
Eye tests are free every 2 years for residents in Scotland.
Opticians can refer you to hospital eye specialists if needed.

üîó Find a dentist
üîó Find an optician

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üß† 6. Mental Health Support
Mental health is taken seriously in Scotland. Services include:

Counselling via GP referral

Crisis lines and walk-in support

University mental health support (for students)

Community mental health services

Helpful links:

üîó Breathing Space Scotland

üîó Samaritans ‚Äì call 116 123 any time, free

üîó NHS Mental Health

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üë∂üèΩ 7. Family & Child Healthcare
Children under 16 receive free:

Vaccinations

School nurse visits

Dental checkups

Vision and hearing screening

New parents can access Health Visitors ‚Äî nurses who support families after childbirth.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üßæ 8. Healthcare Rights & Protection

If you‚Äôve paid the IHS, you‚Äôre entitled to most NHS services during your stay.
You can choose a male or female GP.
Your data is confidential and protected by law.
Emergency services are always free, regardless of immigration status.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
‚úÖ Key Checklist



Task
Status




Register with a GP
‚òê


Know your nearest A&E
‚òê


Learn how to call NHS 111
‚òê


Save emergency contacts
‚òê


Sign up for dental care
‚òê

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
ü§ù Need Help?
If you‚Äôre unsure, contact us via the contact page, and we‚Äôll help you navigate NHS services and connect with trusted local support.
Your health matters. And in Scotland, you‚Äôre not alone.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text: Louis Kimanzi is a conscientious individual who believes in the power of sport as a catalyst for positive change - both globally and locally. With a passion for building communities and unlocking opportunities through sport, Louis exemplifies leadership and vision in both academic and professional arenas.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üéì Academic Achievements
Louis graduated with First Class Honours from the University of Edinburgh, earning a Bachelor of Science in Applied Sports Science. His academic excellence was matched by his active contribution to advancing sports knowledge, especially with a focus on Kenyan athletes.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üìä Research & Innovation
Louis was the lead researcher in a pioneering investigation on the role of carbon fibre shoes in running performance. Collaborating with:

Kenya Academy of Sport
Enda Sportswear
Lornah Kiplagat High Altitude Training Center
University of Edinburgh (funder)

This groundbreaking research led to the publication of a journal article titled:

‚ÄúThe effect of carbon-fibre insoles on the running economy of elite Kenyan athletes‚Äù

It stands out as one of the first biomechanics studies conducted in Kenya using local elite athletes, Kenyan-made shoes, and research led by a Kenyan scientist.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üåç Global Dialogue & Impact
In 2023, Louis presented at the Kenya Academy of Sport‚Äôs 2nd International Sports Conference, where he spoke on:

‚ÄúInvesting in sports infrastructure, equipment, and technology in Kenya.‚Äù

His insights drew from both his scientific background and personal commitment to elevating sport as a development tool in Africa.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üíº Professional Life
Louis currently works as a Product Owner at FanDuel Ltd, a global sports technology giant. His role blends strategic leadership with a deep understanding of user needs in high-performance environments.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üéØ Continuing Education
He is presently pursuing a Master of Science in Sports Policy, Management, and International Development of Sport, with a vision to acquire the tools necessary to shape sustainable sports systems in Kenya and beyond.

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üí¨ Personal Philosophy

‚ÄúSport is not just a game. It‚Äôs a platform for empowerment, identity, and transformation.‚Äù

title: Louis Kimanzi
text:
üåç Connect with Louis

LinkedIn: Louis Kimanzi

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri is a Kenyan political scientist, policy-oriented researcher, educator, and thought leader with a passion for democracy, human rights, and inclusive governance. His work focuses on policing, violence, and the experiences of marginalised communities in Africa.

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üéì Academic Background
Dr.¬†Wairuri holds:

PhD in African Studies, University of Edinburgh
MSc in African Studies, University of Oxford
BA in Political Science and Sociology, University of Nairobi

His academic journey reflects a deep commitment to interrogating systems of power, security, and social justice in Africa.

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üîç Research Focus
Kamau‚Äôs research is widely respected and centres around:

Politics of state policing, police abuse, reform, and accountability
Policing of marginalised, stigmatised, and criminalised groups
Violence, including political violence, terrorism, and urban crime

His scholarship has been published in leading journals such as African Affairs and Africa, and edited volumes like the Routledge Handbook for the Horn of Africa. He currently co-edits a book project on migration and marginalisation in East Africa.
He is an active member of professional networks, including:

British Institute in Eastern Africa (BIEA)
African Studies Association (UK)
Development Studies Association (UK)

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üë®üèΩ‚Äçüè´ Educator & Mentor
Dr.¬†Wairuri is currently a Lecturer in Criminology at Edinburgh Napier University, where he teaches undergraduate and postgraduate courses on policing and transnational crime. He also leads the Institute of Public Policy and Governance (IPPG) at Strathmore University Business School, Nairobi.
He has delivered lectures and seminars at prestigious institutions including:

University of Oxford
University of Cambridge
University of Strathclyde

He is also an Associate Fellow of the Higher Education Academy (UK).

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üß≠ Policy & Public Engagement
As a policy and public affairs consultant, Dr.¬†Wairuri has advised organisations and leaders on:

Safety and security
Gender inclusion and equity
Human rights mainstreaming
Youth empowerment

His work in this space has been captured in technical reports and policy briefs.

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üóûÔ∏è Public Thought Leadership
Kamau is a regular contributor to public debates on governance and social justice. His articles have appeared in:

Daily Nation, The Standard (as a former columnist), and The East African
African Arguments and The Elephant

He is the host of The Kenyanist, a podcast exploring the political and social issues affecting Kenyans today.

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üí¨ In His Words

‚ÄúScholarship should serve society ‚Äì through truth, clarity, and the courage to challenge injustice.‚Äù

title: Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri
text:
üåê Connect with Dr.¬†Kamau Wairuri

Podcast: The Kenyanist
LinkedIn: Kamau Wairuri

title: Summer 2025 Graduates in Scotland
text: We are thrilled to celebrate the achievements of Kenyan graduates across Scotland. This gallery honours our Summer 2025 graduates, beginning with those from Edinburgh Napier University and The University of Edinburgh.

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text: Join us for a rejuvenating summer day out in the Pentland Hills Regional Park. This circular walk from Flotterstone offers panoramic views, peaceful trails, and a wonderful opportunity to connect with nature and fellow community members.

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text: Join us for a rejuvenating summer day out in the Pentland Hills Regional Park. This circular walk from Flotterstone offers panoramic views, peaceful trails, and a wonderful opportunity to connect with nature and fellow community members.

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text:
üóìÔ∏è Date
Saturday, 4th July 2025

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text:
üìç Location
Meeting Point: Usher Hall, Edinburgh
Time: Meet at 7:00 AM for a prompt 7:15 AM departure

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text:
ü•æ Walk Overview

Route: Circular trail via Turnhouse Hill and Carnethy Hill
Distance: ~11 km / 7 miles

Elevation Gain: ~550 meters

Highest Points:

Turnhouse Hill ‚Äì 506‚ÄØm / 1,660‚ÄØft

Carnethy Hill ‚Äì 573‚ÄØm / 1,880‚ÄØft


Difficulty: Moderate

Estimated Duration: 3.5‚Äì4.5 hours (including breaks and photo stops)

This hike is suitable for individuals with a basic to moderate fitness level and includes a mix of steady climbs, rolling hills, and stunning views across Edinburgh and Midlothian.

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text:
üéí What to Bring

Comfortable hiking boots or sturdy walking shoes

Layered clothing and waterproof outerwear

Water and packed lunch/snacks

Sunscreen and a sunhat

Camera or phone for photos

A friendly smile and adventurous spirit!

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text:
üöó Getting There

By car: Free parking is available at the Flotterstone Car Park
By bus: Lothian Buses 101/102 serve the nearby area

Let us know if you‚Äôd like to carpool‚Äîwe‚Äôll do our best to help coordinate rides.

title: Pentland Hills Hike: Saturday, 4 July 2025
text:
üìù Register
Interested in joining us?
üëâ Sign up through the Volunteer form and mention ‚ÄúPentlands Hike‚Äù in the message section.
Or feel free to email us.

We look forward to walking the Pentlands with you!

title: Contact Us

Follow our official accounts to learn about upcoming cultural festivals, community gatherings, professional networking opportunities, and important updates that matter to the Kenyan community living in Scotland. Our platforms also provide a space to celebrate our achievements, share our stories, and support one another.

title: About US
text:
The Kenyan Community in Scotland (KCS) is a vibrant, welcoming network dedicated to connecting, supporting, and empowering Kenyans living across Scotland.
Founded with the vision of fostering a strong, inclusive community, we aim to celebrate our rich Kenyan heritage while promoting integration, collaboration, and success within Scottish society.

title: About US
text:
Our Mission

To create a platform where Kenyans in Scotland can connect, share, and grow together.
To promote cultural exchange, understanding, and appreciation between Kenyans and the wider Scottish community.
To support members through professional networking, mentorship, social events, and community service initiatives.

title: About US
text:
Our Vision
We envision a thriving Kenyan diaspora in Scotland that remains deeply connected to its roots while actively contributing to the social, cultural, and economic fabric of Scottish society.

title: About US
text:
What We Do

Community Events: Organizing cultural celebrations, professional mixers, workshops, and family gatherings.
Support and Advocacy: Offering resources, peer support, and advocacy for newcomers and long-term residents alike.
Partnerships: Collaborating with organizations, businesses, and institutions to create opportunities for our members.
Youth Engagement: Inspiring and mentoring the next generation of Kenyan-Scots.

title: About US
text:
Get Involved
Whether you are new to Scotland or have called it home for years, we invite you to join us.
Together, we can build a community that uplifts every member and celebrates the best of who we are.
üëâ Join the Community
üëâ Partner with US


Connecting Roots and Building Futures

title: Accessibility Commitment
text: The Kenyan Community in Scotland is committed to ensuring digital accessibility for all visitors to our website, including people with disabilities. We aim to make our website and content as accessible, inclusive, and user-friendly as possible.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Our Commitment
We strive to:

Design content that is usable and readable for everyone.
Ensure that our website is navigable by keyboard and assistive technologies.
Provide text alternatives for non-text content, such as images.
Maintain high contrast between text and background colors.
Use clear and simple language wherever possible.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Accessibility Features
Our website includes the following features:

Responsive design that works across desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.
Alternative text descriptions for images.
Accessible navigation menus.
Logical heading structures to assist screen readers.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Ongoing Improvements
We recognize that accessibility is an ongoing effort. We are continuously reviewing and updating our website to improve usability for all users.
If you encounter any accessibility barriers or have suggestions for improvements, we welcome your feedback.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Contact Us
We value your input and want to ensure everyone can access our content with ease. If you encounter any issues or have suggestions to help us improve accessibility:

 üõ†Ô∏è Report an Accessibility Issue

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text: Take on the highest mountain in the UK. Join us for an unforgettable summer hiking challenge as we summit Ben Nevis (1,345‚ÄØm / 4,413‚ÄØft), one of Scotland‚Äôs most iconic peaks.

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text: Take on the highest mountain in the UK. Join us for an unforgettable summer hiking challenge as we summit Ben Nevis (1,345‚ÄØm / 4,413‚ÄØft), one of Scotland‚Äôs most iconic peaks.

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
üóìÔ∏è Date
Saturday, 19th July 2025

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
üìç Location
Meeting Point: Usher Hall, Edinburgh
Time: Departure to for the Mountain Path at 4:00 AM

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
üèûÔ∏è About Ben Nevis
Located near the town of Fort William in the Scottish Highlands, Ben Nevis is a magnet for hikers and mountaineers. The trail offers breathtaking views, rugged beauty, and a true sense of accomplishment.

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
ü•æ Hike Overview

Route: Mountain Track (also known as the Tourist Route)
Distance: ~17 km round trip
Elevation Gain: ~1,350 meters
Difficulty: Strenuous
Estimated Duration: 7‚Äì9 hours

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
üéí What to Bring

Sturdy hiking boots
Weather-appropriate clothing (layers, waterproofs)
Plenty of water and snacks
Sun protection and personal first aid kit
Trekking poles (optional but helpful)

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Important Notes

Weather in the Highlands can change rapidly. Be prepared for rain, wind, or fog.
This hike is physically demanding ‚Äî a good fitness level is required.
Children under 16 must be accompanied by a responsible adult.

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
üöó Travel
Participants are encouraged to arrange carpooling. Let us know in advance if you can offer or need a lift.

title: Ben Nevis Hike: Saturday, 19th July 2025
text:
üìù Register
Interested in joining? Please contact us or fill out the Volunteer form and mention Ben Nevis Hike in the message.

Let‚Äôs summit the UK‚Äôs tallest mountain together!

title: Linus Chirchir
text: Linus Chirchir is a passionate data scientist based in Edinburgh and a founding force behind the Kenyan Community in Scotland website. With over a decade of experience in health information systems, research, and analytics, Linus has dedicated his career to driving data-informed decisions that make a real-world impact.

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üíº Professional Journey
Originally from Kenya, Linus worked at Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital where he managed integrated health information systems and supported research and analytics. After completing his MSc in Health Data Science at Swansea University, he joined the University of Edinburgh as a Health Data Analyst.
Currently, he works at Research Data Scotland (RDS) as a Data Analyst, where he prepares ADR Scotland datasets for integration into Scotland‚Äôs National Safe Haven. His work includes data cleaning, transformation, anonymisation, quality assessment, documentation, and collaboration with cross-functional teams.
He specialises in:

Synthetic data generation

Reproducible analytical pipelines (RAP)

GIS and public health data visualisation

Ethical AI and open science

R, SQL, Quarto, and Shiny app development

Linus finds purpose in applying technical expertise to real-world datasets that inform impactful research and policy.

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üèôÔ∏è Life in Edinburgh
Since moving to Scotland, Linus has been deeply engaged in local and national community-building. Whether he‚Äôs coordinating Munro climbs, organising community mixers, or mentoring students, he fosters unity and wellness through action.
He believes in the power of shared experiences, storytelling, and open conversations - often over a hike or meal - to strengthen community bonds.

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üí¨ In His Words

‚ÄúData is more than numbers, it‚Äôs about people, equity, and opportunity. And community gives our work meaning.‚Äù

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üéì Education

MSc in Health Data Science, Swansea University

Master of Business Administration, United States International University ‚Äì Africa

Master of Information Systems, Kisii University

Bachelor of Business Management (Business Information Systems Management), Moi University

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
‚ú® Highlights & Reflections

Professional Highlight: Working with interdisciplinary teams at RDS to enable safe, ethical access to administrative data and support data-driven research.
Professional Challenge: Keeping pace with evolving best practices and technologies in large-scale data environments ‚Äî addressed through ongoing learning and collaboration.
Inspiration: Hans Rosling ‚Äî his data storytelling approach transformed Linus‚Äô view of analytics as a force for good.
Advice That Stuck: ‚ÄúStay curious and keep learning.‚Äù Change, as Heraclitus said, is the only constant ‚Äî and Linus embraces it as an opportunity to grow.
Fun Fact: His Mastermind subject would be Olympic Marathon Champions (1960‚Äì2024).

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üåç Connect with Linus

Personal site: linuschirchir.com

LinkedIn: Linus Chirchir

GitHub: @linuschirchir

Facebook: ChirchirLinus1

X: @LinusChirchir

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
A UK bank account is essential for:

Getting paid (salary, benefits, stipends)
Paying rent, bills, and subscriptions
Building a credit history
Sending money internationally

You‚Äôll need to open either a basic current account or a student account, depending on your situation.

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
A UK bank account is essential for:

Getting paid (salary, benefits, stipends)
Paying rent, bills, and subscriptions
Building a credit history
Sending money internationally

You‚Äôll need to open either a basic current account or a student account, depending on your situation.

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üè¶ 1. Types of Banks to Consider

üèõÔ∏è Traditional Banks:

Barclays

Lloyds Bank

Halifax

HSBC

NatWest

Bank of Scotland
Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS)



üì± Digital-First Banks:

Monzo

Starling

Revolut (also supports international transfers)

üìå Tip: Digital banks are quicker to set up and require fewer documents ‚Äî ideal if you‚Äôve just arrived.

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üìÑ 2. Documents You Need
Most banks require:

Proof of identity: passport or biometric residence permit (BRP)

Proof of address: tenancy agreement, utility bill, or a letter from your university/employer

üîê Some banks may accept a letter from your university or the Post Office EasyID app for verification.

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üß≠ 3. How to Open an Account

Apply online via the bank‚Äôs website or app (for digital banks)
Or visit a branch in person for traditional banks
Submit ID and address documents
Wait for approval (may take hours to a few days)
Receive your debit card and PIN by post

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üí° 4. Features to Look For

No monthly fees (most basic accounts are free)
Contactless card + online banking
Mobile app for money transfers
Direct debit and standing order options
Overdraft protection or student incentives (for student accounts)

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üîÑ 5. Sending & Receiving Money

UK Transfers: Use account number and sort code

International Transfers: Use SWIFT/BIC and IBAN

Apps like Wise, WorldRemit, and Revolut offer affordable remittance options for sending money back to Kenya

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üîê 6. Banking Safety Tips

Never share your PIN or login details

Enable biometric login on banking apps

Watch out for fake emails (phishing scams)

Report lost cards immediately

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üë®üèΩ‚Äçüéì 7. Student Banking
If you‚Äôre a student: - Ask your university for a proof of student status letter - Many banks offer student-specific accounts with perks (e.g., free railcards)
Popular student-friendly banks: - Santander (16‚Äì25 Railcard) - HSBC - RBS (in Scotland)

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üßæ 8. Building Your Financial Footprint

Pay your bills on time (e.g., mobile contract)
Avoid unnecessary overdraft usage
Register on the electoral roll
Consider small savings or budgeting apps

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
‚úÖ Quick Checklist



Task
Status




Choose a bank
‚òê


Gather ID and address documents
‚òê


Apply online or visit a branch
‚òê


Set up mobile banking app
‚òê


Enable alerts and security settings
‚òê

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üí¨ Need Help?
Have questions? Our Contact page is open ‚Äî or join the community on Facebook to ask for advice from fellow Kenyans.
A bank account is your first financial step. We‚Äôre here to help you take it with confidence.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text: Moving to Scotland from Kenya is an exciting journey, but it can also feel overwhelming at first. This guide walks you through the essential steps for settling in, with helpful resources, legal guidance, and local support links.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text: Moving to Scotland from Kenya is an exciting journey, but it can also feel overwhelming at first. This guide walks you through the essential steps for settling in, with helpful resources, legal guidance, and local support links.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üìå 1. Visa Types and Application
Depending on your purpose, you‚Äôll apply for one of these visas:

Student Visa ‚Äì For those studying at a university or college.
Skilled Worker Visa ‚Äì For individuals with job offers in eligible occupations.
Family Visa ‚Äì For joining a spouse, child, or parent.
Visitor Visa ‚Äì Short-term stay (e.g.¬†tourism, business, or visiting family).
Graduate Visa ‚Äì For students who have completed their UK studies.

üîó Check which UK visa you need

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üìÑ 2. Documents You‚Äôll Need
Ensure you have these key documents ready:

Valid passport

Visa confirmation (BRP or digital status)

Proof of accommodation in Scotland

NHS registration (after arrival)

TB test certificate (for long-term visas)

Police registration (if required)

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üè† 3. Finding a Place to Live
Housing options include:

University accommodation (for students)

Private rentals ‚Äì via Rightmove, Zoopla, or Gumtree

Council or social housing (in special cases)

üìå Tip: Get a tenancy agreement and avoid cash-only landlords.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üè• 4. Healthcare and the NHS

Once you arrive, register with a local GP (doctor).
Access to healthcare is mostly free through the NHS, but some services like prescriptions may have fees.
Emergency: Dial 999

Non-emergency: Dial 111

üîó Find a local GP

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üíº 5. National Insurance Number
You‚Äôll need a National Insurance (NI) Number to work legally and pay taxes in the UK.
üîó Apply online for an NI Number

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
section: üìö 6. Settling In: What Else to Do
text:
üìö 6. Settling In: What Else to Do

Open a bank account: Use Monzo, Revolut, or traditional banks (Barclays, Lloyds, etc.)
Get a SIM card: Giffgaff, Lebara, or EE offer good deals for international calls
Know your rights: Especially if you‚Äôre a tenant or employee
Attend local orientation events: Check our Events

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üåç Community & Support
You don‚Äôt have to do this alone. Join other Kenyans in Scotland:

Connect via Kenyan Community in Scotland
Follow us on Facebook or Instagram
Explore cultural events and mixers in Edinburgh and Glasgow

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
‚úÖ Checklist Before & After Arrival



Task
Status




Apply for visa
‚òê


Book accommodation
‚òê


Confirm airport pickup
‚òê


Register with GP
‚òê


Attend KCS welcome session
‚òê

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
ü§ù Need Help?
Reach out to us via contact page or email info@kenyancommunityinscotland.uk.
We‚Äôre here to make your transition smooth, safe, and successful. Karibu Scotland!

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
On Saturday, 2 March 2024, members of the Kenyan Community in Scotland gathered in Glasgow to attend the World Athletics Indoor Championships 2024, showing support and solidarity with Team Kenya at the Emirates Arena. It was a celebration of excellence, pride, and unity.
 The SSE Hydro and SEC Armadillo en route to the event
We started the day travelling through iconic Glasgow landmarks, eventually arriving at the venue, which buzzed with anticipation and flags from every corner of the world.
 Crowds approaching Emirates Arena
 Emirates Arena entrance with event banners

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
On Saturday, 2 March 2024, members of the Kenyan Community in Scotland gathered in Glasgow to attend the World Athletics Indoor Championships 2024, showing support and solidarity with Team Kenya at the Emirates Arena. It was a celebration of excellence, pride, and unity.
 The SSE Hydro and SEC Armadillo en route to the event
We started the day travelling through iconic Glasgow landmarks, eventually arriving at the venue, which buzzed with anticipation and flags from every corner of the world.
 Crowds approaching Emirates Arena

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
section: üëã Connecting with Fellow Kenyans and Fans
text:
üëã Connecting with Fellow Kenyans and Fans
Inside, it was more than just athletics - it was a mini-reunion. We met other passionate fans and supporters of Team Kenya from across Scotland and beyond.
 Selfie with fans in full Kenyan gear
The crowd energy was contagious as we watched heats, sprints, hurdles, jumps, and more.
 A packed Emirates Arena during one of the sessions
 Spectators following the events attentively
 Track view of athletes and audience
 More views of the vibrant arena

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
ü•â Kenya on the Podium
A proud moment came when Beatrice Chepkoech secured a bronze medal in the Women‚Äôs 3000 metres, clocking 8:22.68, a new national record.
 Chepkoech smiles alongside the Ethiopian winner after the Women‚Äôs 3000m final

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
üç¥ Post-Event Meetup and Reflections
After the event, the Kenyan community met up to reflect and share a meal. We gathered at the athlete hotel and later visited Kenyan-owned local spots in Glasgow to celebrate.
 Meeting Kenyan athletes and supporters at the hotel lounge
 Post-race group celebration over drinks and Tusker
 Dinner with Kenyan team officials and staff

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
üì∏ Bonus Highlights
We captured even more moments from the stands and during athlete warm-ups:
 Kenyan fan overlooking the arena
 Side view of the packed venue during live events
 Broadcast setup and track overview
 Group photo with Beatrice Chepkoech at the hotel
 Chilling out with the Kenyan delegation at the hotel cafe

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
üôå Thank You and Asanteni Sana!
To every Kenyan who turned up, cheered loudly, and waved our flag with pride, thank you. Your presence and passion made this day unforgettable.
Let‚Äôs continue showing up for each other, whether on the track or in everyday life.

Stay connected for future meetups, sports outings, and cultural events.
üì¨ Subscribe to community updates or Join the Volunteer List

title: Volunteer with Us
text: We believe that building a strong community starts with passionate individuals who are willing to give their time, skills, and energy. Whether you are looking to make a difference, meet new people, or share your expertise, we welcome you to volunteer with us!

title: Volunteer with Us
text:
Why Volunteer?

Make a Positive Impact: Help foster a vibrant, supportive Kenyan community in Scotland.
Develop New Skills: Gain experience in event management, community outreach, mentoring, and more.
Build Connections: Meet fellow Kenyans and friends of Kenya living across Scotland.

title: Volunteer with Us
text:
Volunteer Opportunities
We offer a range of volunteering opportunities, including:

Event Support: Assist with planning and organizing cultural festivals, networking events, and family days.
Community Outreach: Help us connect with new members and promote community engagement.
Mentorship Programs: Share your knowledge and experience to support students, professionals, and families.
Content Creation: Help us create blogs, newsletters, social media content, and more.

No matter your skills or background, there is a place for you in our community!

title: Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike: Saturday, 16 August 2025
text:
Join us for an unforgettable summer hike in Glen Etive as we take on one or both of the spectacular Munros that form Buachaille Etive M√≤r: Stob Dearg (1,022‚ÄØm / 3,353‚ÄØft) and Stob na Br√≤ige (956‚ÄØm / 3,136‚ÄØft).
This iconic ridge walk offers breathtaking panoramic views over Glencoe, Rannoch Moor, and the Etive Valley is a must-do for any Scottish hillwalker.

text:

title: Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike: Saturday, 16 August 2025
text:
üìç Location
Meeting Point: Usher Hall, Edinburgh
Departure Time: 05:00 AM sharp
Note: An early start is essential due to the travel distance and hike duration.

title: Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike: Saturday, 16 August 2025
text:
ü•æ Hike Overview

Distance: ~13‚Äì15 km (depending on whether one or both Munros are summited)

Elevation Gain: ~1,000 metres

Difficulty: Strenuous

Duration: 6‚Äì8 hours (including breaks)

Terrain: Rocky paths, steep ascents, exposed ridge walking

Participants may choose to:

Climb Stob Dearg only (the main summit)

Continue along the ridge to include Stob na Br√≤ige

Or, if you‚Äôve already done Stob Dearg, focus on Stob na Br√≤ige this time

title: Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike: Saturday, 16 August 2025
text:
üéí What to Bring

Sturdy hiking boots

Waterproof and windproof outerwear

Hat, gloves, and warm layers

Packed lunch and high-energy snacks

At least 2 litres of water

Walking poles (optional but recommended)

Sunscreen and midge repellent

title: Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike: Saturday, 16 August 2025
text:
üöó Travel
Carpooling may be arranged. Please let us know early if you can offer or need a lift when registering. Avoid last-minute cancellations, especially if you‚Äôre part of a shared transport arrangement, as it affects planning. Fuel and parking costs will be shared among passengers.

title: Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike: Saturday, 16 August 2025
text:
üìù Register
To take part, email us or fill out the volunteer form, mentioning Buachaille Etive M√≤r Hike in your message.

We look forward to an exhilarating and scenic day in the Highlands.
See you on the trail!

title: Climbing Ben Nevis: Conquering the UK‚Äôs Highest Peak
text: On Saturday, 19th July 2025, members and friends of the Kenyan Community in Scotland came together for a monumental hike up Ben Nevis (1,345‚ÄØm / 4,413‚ÄØft), the highest mountain in the British Isles. Our journey began at Glen Nevis, following a well-established trail to the summit.

title: Climbing Ben Nevis: Conquering the UK‚Äôs Highest Peak
text:
üèîÔ∏è The Ascent Begins
We left Edinburgh bright and early at 5:00 AM, gathering at Usher Hall with backpacks, snacks, and anticipation. Arriving at Glen Nevis Visitor Centre by 9:00 AM, we began our steady ascent under mild summer skies.
The trail welcomed us with sweeping valley views, laughter, and shared excitement.

title: Climbing Ben Nevis: Conquering the UK‚Äôs Highest Peak
text:
üì∏ Journey Highlights

Starting the Hike

Early in the hike with energy high, legs fresh, and scenery already stunning

Spirits flying high among lush greenery

Taking a breather and soaking up the Highland panorama



Midway Challenges and Highland Drama

A trail of determined hikers weaving up the mountain

The climb is tough, but views like this make it worth it
 Loch Linnhe and Loch Eil stretch below, a rewarding sight from high above.

A quick break before the final push, taking in the beauty and bonding.

Misty and cold but that didn‚Äôt stop the smiles at the summit cairn.



Summit Celebrations

A dramatic view near the summit ridge.

Proudly representing Kenya at the top of the UK

Ben Nevis summit in full swing with hikers from around the world.


Mission accomplished at the UK‚Äôs highest point
Misty and cold ‚Äî but that didn‚Äôt stop the smiles at the summit cairn.

Grins, grit, and great heights ‚Äî a misty summit moment to remember.



The Descent

Tired legs and full hearts as we descend toward the valley

title: Climbing Ben Nevis: Conquering the UK‚Äôs Highest Peak
text:
üí¨ Reflections
For many, this was their first time summiting Ben Nevis, a physical and mental challenge that brought out the best in everyone. The group spirit was unshakable, with friends cheering one another on and making the journey memorable from first step to final descent.
It wasn‚Äôt just about reaching the top, it was about connection, resilience, and pride in our collective effort.

title: Climbing Ben Nevis: Conquering the UK‚Äôs Highest Peak
text:
üôå Acknowledgements
Special thanks to all who made this adventure a success ‚Äî from organising transport and preparing gear to leading, encouraging, and celebrating together.
